content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Tested and working for Python. Solved using scalar product. Clear statement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved in less than 4 minutes using pythagorean theorem.
You can avoid float issues by keeping all lengths squared.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Note: Default code gives an error in Clojure, but I don't see any way around it.

The first method I tried using Pythagoras gave inexact equality with floats. Workable, but ugly. The second method with dot product gave a nicer solution. In each case it took at least 10 minutes. So this is likely to be challenging just to complete in time.

Maybe give a hint to steer in the direction of dot product? I would also suggest not using zero coordinates in so many of your test cases, as it tends to pass too easily if the formulas aren't set up right. Limit to the first case.
Nice problem but a big NO for the reverse mode.

OK you should be right. I  imagine that the stub gives you sufficient hint on what to do but that may not be the spirit of the reverse mode which should be more on understanding input and output relation than guessing it by reading default code.
I removed reverse mode

Indeed I will put a hint on the pythagoras theorm.
And translate the exemple points to have fewer 0.
Thanks for your comments.

Thanks for approving.
And thanks for spotting the problem with Clojure.
I fixed it (there was a tab character after the first input: number of points).

In shortest mode, I have something like this:

I=input
p=[]
for _ in '$'*int(I()):x,y=I().split();p+=[(int(x),int(y))]
c=0
for a,(u,v)in enumerate(p):
 for b,(m,n)in enumerate(p[:a]):
  for x,y in p[:b]:
   d,e,f=sorted([(u-m)**2+(v-n)**2,(u-x)**2+(v-y)**2,(x-m)**2+(y-n)**2])
   c+=[0,1][f==d+e]
I(c)
To be clear, that one worked but it was inexact, so I had to give it an epsilon. The one that was spot on was (x1-x2)*(x1-x3)+(y1-y2)*(y1-y3)==0 since there are no roots or even division.
Sorry davilla, I don't see why it is inexact. We only add or substract integers and then put it to square. Maybe you used also a square root but it is useless in pythagoras theorem

Oh of course, I should have thought of that. Yeah I was dumb, rooting to find the length of each side, instead of just leaving it squared. Anyway the dot product approach was better, but now I'm wondering if they aren't actually equivalent. Sorry for all the rambling then.
I understood just now your formula : dot product between AB vector and AC vector. It is indeed 0 if the angle in A is right-angled. So your solution is correct too and also works only with integers.

Cool. :-) By the way, probably most everyone already knows Pythagoras. The hint could simply be something like: A right triangle can be checked either by using the Pythagorean theorem, or by testing that the dot product of two side vectors is zero.
